content.description:
Welcome to Lakeview follows in a long time S. California tradition of naming a quality route at a crag; Welcome to.... as in Welcome to Joshua Tree, Welcome to Texas Canyon, Welcome to Dome Rock, in honor of Herb Laeger.

WTLV begins at the base of the L-Slab below a wide crack, as for Bloody L. Climb the wide crack or the face to the left to a crack. As Blood L moves left continue up the face crossing the crack as it curves left. Climb the featured face above past four bolts to the anchor. Caution...WTLV is a rope stretcher. Better to lower/rappel to the base uphill from the start and also tie a knot in the end of the rope to close the system.
content.location: WTLV climbs the wide crack in the middle of L-Slab and the face above.

content.description: From the ledge move right and paddle up the slab past 3 bolts. There's a long runout from the last bolt to the anchor.
Climb the slab left of the crack/seam of Bloody L. past two bolts. Continue up the featured slab to a dke. Follow the dike up and right for 10 - 15 feet past another bolt and  the anchor.

climbs.name: Regular Route Direct
climbs.fa: Craig Britton and Chris Miller, February 2010

content.description: Climb the face below a left curving arc/crack past one bolt. Continue climbing through the left trending arc/crack. The crack takes medium cams. Above climb the face on small face features and fiction past four more bolts.
content.location: Left side of the L-Slab. Second line of bolts from the left.

content.description: Move right from the ledge and climb to the 1st bolt. Continue up the slab past a 2nd bolt. Above the route joins Glory Days to paddle up the slab past two more bolts and the anchor.

Tenuous slab paddling up the blunt arête that bypasses a lower anchor on the left and continues to hug the right arete until the large ledge at the top.

Best to get on this when the temperature is cooler.
content.location: Furthest route on the right and starting around the right side of the arête.

content.description: Climb the left margin of the L-Slab, up the undulating water course, to where the slab steepens and holds diminish. Continue up the slab past four bolts on small edges and fiction. There are 3 or 4 nice shallow holes or depressions along the way. If clipping the 1st bolt on Regular Route Direct and placing cams in the crack/arch of that route the start is reasonably well protected. Without this protection the climbing to the 1st bolt is unprotected, but not harder than 5.7.
content.protection: 4 bolts and shares a 2-ring Fixe ring anchor (+ one bolt w/ hanger) with Regular Route Direct.

content.description: Traverse in, moving right, from the ledge. Glory Days climbs the right edge of the L-Slab past five bolts on smooth polished slab.

Begin climbing below a wide crack that begins 10 ft the slab. The climbing in the crack/face is easy, but a large cam might make the belayer happy. Continue moving leftward up the face to an overlap which accepts cams/nuts. Climb the featured face above the overlap past four more bolts to the anchor. Beware...even with a 70 meter rope this pitch is a rope stretcher. Better to lower the climber to the base near the left side of the slab and the belayer moves up slope and has a knot in the end of the rope.
content.location: Middle of the slab, below a wider crack that begins 10 ft above the base.
